It is estimated that extreme climate processes, such as the El Nino Southern Oscillation, will increase as a result of associated global warming changing convection currents in both the oceans and the atmosphere. The evolving international and domestic regulations and policies in favour of environmentally friendly technology may however reduce the impact of human activity on the atmosphere.
Likely Response: Elevated release of atmospheric contaminants is required to maximize dilution potential of the atmosphere.
Effect on Variability: The type of industrial plant influences emission heights - e.g. 1000MW fossil-fuel burning power plants have stacks up to 300 metres in height while nuclear power plants can have roof-level vents.

Justification: Weather conditions can affect water in a number of different ways. Variations in rainfall patterns will cause water quality changes which will impact drinking water production and human health. Rising temperatures can increase evaporation, reducing the quantity of water in a given location.
Likely Response: Increases or decreases in the amount of rainfall and solar energy available on a regional/local basis.
Effect on Variability: Increased or decreased water balances within landscapes.
Timescale: Short term - Daily to seasonal variation in rainfall and cloud cover that affects how solar energy impacts water in landscapes. Mid-term - Inter-annual variation in rainfall. Long term - Decadal variation in rainfall patterns.
Spatial Characteristics: Regional - Rainfall patterns and solar energy are highly region-specific, for example tropical regions get periodic monsoons and dry months throughout the year, whereas temperate regions have more seasonal weather patterns.
